title: Ticket #5550: Job routes require "target" scoping _only_ in Requirements
description:
Job routes have two nasty gotchas:
  • The Requirements line must use target scoping. I.e., (foo =?= "bar") always evaluates to False because you must use (target.foo =?= "bar").
  • None of the job transform rules (eval_set_, set_, etc) may use target scoping. Hence, you end up in this strange situation where one attribute needs a different set of rules than everything else.

Seems this should be easy to clean up and make less annoying for the unsuspecting sysadmin.
remarks:
2016-Mar-09 10:30:17 by jfrey:
Making the Target scope optional is implemented partially in the ClassAds library and partially in the compatibility layer inside the Condor utils library. The Job Router's evaluation of route requirements bypasses the compatibility layer.

To make this work, we need to move some of the code into the ClassAds library. Specifically, the MatchClassAd object needs to set ClassAd::alternateScope in the two candidate ads. It would only do this if _useOldClassAdSemantics is set to true.

2016-Mar-09 13:19:46 by jfrey:
With the change I'm proposing, TARGET will no longer be required in the requirements expression. Using it in the other expressions will still not work.

Is 8.5.x okay for this change?

2016-Mar-11 14:17:22 by jfrey:
Other expressions in a job route that affect the router's behavior also require a target scope. These include JobFailureTest, UseSharedX509UserProxy, and JobShouldBeSandboxed.

2016-Apr-29 09:54:21 by johnkn:
code review: looks good.

2016-Oct-07 13:26:31 by jfrey:
Clarification: After this change, none of the expressions in a route ad need a Target. prefix to reference attributes in the job ad. One exception is if the route and job ad contain an attribute with the same name.
